title: What are the different ways of coding the emails? Hint â€“ Fixed, Responsive, Fluid
content: Fixed / Statick ==> These layouts are good for desktop-only designs with a static width and height. The elements that exist within the layout do not shift as per the screen size or when the user minimizes the window.
point1: FLUID ==> Fluid designs are meant to be used for mobile and desktops. As the user minimizes the browser or makes use of the smaller screen, the elements within their containers tend to shift
point2: Adaptive or Responsive ==> adaptive layouts stacks one below each other on mobile devices

title: DPI Scaling Issues / common outlook issues?
content: Outlook converts pixels to points inconsistently throughout your email, so parts of your code will render differently.
point1: We use special tag to scale VML inside style tag
point2: Need to define cellspacing and cellpadding for table and mso-cellspacing, mso-padding-alt
point3: Whiteline issues: Adjust heights and font sizes from odd to even font size, also can be fixed by adding mso specific code mso-table-lspace: 0pt; mso-table-rspace: 0pt;border-collapse:collapse;
point4: Link issues: wrap the link in a and style the span
point5: Font stacks and Times New Roman: By putting your custom font last in the list
point6: Controlling line height in Outlook using border-collapes:collapse for tr,td and mso-line-height-rule:exactly;
